image.altText: A graphic containing a silhouette of a side profile of a woman's face. A road sign that says 'Palmerston' is in the background

items.synopsis: A coronial inquest into Miss Yunupiŋu's death is exploring how she felt pressure from some relatives to reunite with her abusive partner leading up to her death.

title.children: Shame, coercion and a failing prison system: An inquest into one woman's death is laying bare the NT's domestic violence crisis

image.altText: woman looking down

items.synopsis: The rising costs of living are increasing pressure on some international students to make difficult choices, such as paying for rent instead of mental health appointments.

title.children: Evania is forced to prioritise paying $470 per week to rent a room in Sydney over mental health care

image.altText: APN: Putin Forum

items.synopsis: Alexei Navalny urged Russians to dump the country's authoritarian regime. He's just been jailed for 19 years, but the thing that keeps him awake in his bunk at night might surprise you.

title.children: Putin's biggest rival is in 'one of the worst places in the world' — this is what it's like

image.altText: A soccer player wearing blue and light green leans on her knees with an Australian flag in the background

items.synopsis: For 96 gruelling minutes, they tried to make history on the pitch. But for these exhausted Matildas, their race was already run.

title.children: Matildas' loss to Sweden revealed a team that had already given everything

image.altText: Five quick hits

items.synopsis: Katrina Gorry's temper boils over against Sweden, while Matildas coach Tony Gustavsson finally looked to use his bench — these are the five quick hits from the Matildas final World Cup match,

title.children: Five quick hits — Gorry gets angry in push and shove as Gustavsson finally looks to his subs

image.altText: Sad Sam Kerr

items.synopsis: The Matildas fall 2-0 to Sweden in the third-place playoff at the FIFA Women's World Cup, bringing to an end comfortably Australia greatest showing at football's global showpiece tournament.

title.children: Tired and frustrated Matildas fall short in third-place playoff with Sweden to end World Cup run

image.altText: A close up of a pair of hands scooping up water

items.synopsis: In the dry, dusty town of Oodnadatta in central Australia, water has not only been a precious commodity, but one that has not been safe to drink.

title.children: Residents of this remote town were missing the 'basic human right' of clean drinking water, until last month

image.altText: Sillouette of ski chair lifts in snowy atmosphere

items.synopsis: An investigation is underway after a ski chair lift plummeted to the ground below in the New South Wales Snowy Mountains, injuring three people.

title.children: Three injured after chair lift plunges into snow below at NSW ski resort

image.altText: car with broken window in front of damaged building

items.synopsis: Civilians in Chernihiv were on their way to celebrate a religious holiday when the missile strike hit the city's central square.

title.children: 'Day of pain and loss': At least 7 dead, 129 injured in strike on Ukrainian city square

image.altText: A composite of two men looking away from the camera

items.synopsis: This is not the first time prosthetic noses have popped up on screen and caused controversies towards the Jewish community.

title.children: Bradley Cooper has been accused of 'Jewface' over his new movie — here's what that means

image.altText: three forks and their shadows on a sea green background

items.synopsis: Australians spend an average of 31 years of their lives on a diet yet we remain one of the most statistically overweight people in the world. Does anything work to shift unwanted kilos?

title.children: The word 'diet' looms over weight loss, but science now has a different answer

image.altText: A before and after shot of a social media app changing the shape of a woman's body

items.synopsis: People have been aware of photoshopped images in magazines and on social media for years, but a new study has found young women are less likely to believe that videos can also be edited.

title.children: Undetectable social media filters allowing women to change their bodies in videos

image.altText: Two logging machines have been graffitied with the words "who will fight the bushfires?"

items.synopsis: Native logging will no longer be allowed in two states from next year, and there are calls for other jurisdictions to follow suit. But some experts and industry representatives say the bans could be devastating for developing nations.

title.children: Forestry industry pushes back against mounting calls for nationwide native logging ban

image.altText: Flames emerge from the bottom of a rocket as it lifts off

items.synopsis: An "abnormal situation" strikes Russia's Luna-25 spacecraft as it prepares to transfer to its pre-landing orbit, according to Russia's national space agency Roskosmos.

title.children: 'Abnormal situation' strikes Russian spacecraft on mission to explore Moon's south pole

image.altText: People with red capes chant in the street

items.synopsis: While outrage over an ABC television crew filming a protest outside the Woodside CEO's home dominated headlines, Kathryn Diss questions whether the chaos of climate action could be more harmful than helpful.

title.children: Climate activism has dominated headlines, but has the mayhem muddied the message?

image.altText: Five young men dance on the sand in front of a rock shelf.

items.synopsis: Combining ancient songlines with punk, metal and rock music influences, Arnhem Land band Wildfire Manwurrk sings in the endangered Kune language to keep it alive.

title.children: From jamming in an Arnhem Land cave to the National Indigenous Music Awards, this band is one to watch

image.altText: epkd_PoliceVideo_1808

items.synopsis: The national children's commissioner is calling for an NT Police promotional video of officers chasing and arresting two teenagers to be taken down.

title.children: 'Potentially dangerous': Children's commissioner slams NT Police promotional video

image.altText: Nathan Finn (1)

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory Police Association's new president has used his first public speech to slam successive NT government policies and "rushed and bungled" rollouts he says are failing frontline officers.

title.children: NT police union president uses first public speech to highlight 'crisis' within force

image.altText: Tamara Oudyn smiles, standing in stage with a choir of women dressed in denim.

items.synopsis: We seem to love making fun of the "daggy" image of the community choir — but the truth is, there's a mountain of evidence backing up how they boost our wellbeing, writes ABC News presenter Tamara Oudyn.

title.children: Lots of Australians reckon community choirs are 'daggy'. Here's why they're wrong

image.altText: The word 'memory' is spelled out in billowing clouds of water vapour on a gridded wall in a gallery.

items.synopsis: Mexican artist-chemist Rafael Lozano-Hemmer has created an odyssey for existential dilemmas using ‘inversive’ technology.

title.children: 'The seduction of participation': Immersive artwork co-opts audience as comment on surveillance

image.altText: Pakistan Shah Qureshi

items.synopsis: The vice-chairman of jailed Pakistani former prime minister Imran Khan's party is arrested, as part of a widening crackdown on the former ruling party.

title.children: Pakistan's opposition party leader Shah Mehmood Qureshi detained

image.altText: Two men wearing green and red striped guernseys

items.synopsis: South Sydney premiership-winner and Indigenous All Stars representative Kyle Turner has died at the age of 31. Warning: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised that this article contains images and the name of a person who has died.

title.children: Souths NRL premiership-winner Kyle Turner dies aged 31

image.altText: Woman curled up with hands over abdomen

items.synopsis: In the short-term, inflammation is a sign your body is healing. But persistent levels of inflammation in blood and tissue — called "inflammaging" — is linked to disease, write Lauren Ball and Emily Burch.

title.children: Nine signs you have chronic inflammation in your body

image.altText: Geelong AFL players walk off the field following a loss to St Kilda/

items.synopsis: The Cats' slim chances of back-to-back flags are dashed following a sloppy performance against the Saints, while the Swans finish off Adelaide's season with a thrilling one-point win after the Crows thought they had snatched victory in the final minute of the match.

title.children: Inaccurate Saints sink reigning premiers' season as Swans end Crows' hopes in tense finish

image.altText: A Melbourne Storm NRL player runs the ball tucked under his right arm.

items.synopsis: Melbourne Storm sneak home against St George Illawarra, while Penrith will finish the round in top spot and Wests Tigers record their first win since May.

title.children: Storm survive scare as Panthers move back on top of NRL ladder and Tigers snap losing streak

image.altText: A giant cheese platter showcasing wedges of the companies cheese varieties.

items.synopsis: A boutique outfit from South Gippsland has been named "supreme artisan" on the international stage, cementing Australia's presence as a force to be reckoned with in the world of specialty cheese.

title.children: Australian cheesemakers snatch glory from France and Italy for the first time in 125 years

image.altText: A photograph, taken from above, of dozens of umbrellas and sunlounges on a sandy beach.

items.synopsis: On this Greek island, going to many beaches now comes with a price tag — while locals there are fighting back, the concept of paying for a spot on the sand is starting to be seen Down Under.

title.children: 'People are very, very angry': When tourists swamped this island's beaches, locals decided to act

image.altText: man in suit rubbing hands together next to logo of a white x on black background

items.synopsis: There has been widespread opposition over news the social media platform, formerly known as Twitter, could lose the safety feature.

title.children: X criticised after Elon Musk moves to scrap blocking feature on social media platform

image.altText: A woman taking a selfie in a car through an instragram filter.

items.synopsis: The sudden death of an Indigenous woman in northern New South Wales prompts an outpouring of emotion at a rally in her home town against alleged systemic injustice.

title.children: Family and friends rally in grief and anger over death of young mother Jamikka Binge-Olive

image.altText: The Hancock family in front of a small aircraft

items.synopsis: The portrait of a smiling family captured in 1976 gives little indication of the tensions that would later erupt between the generations — and 40 years later, the feud in the House of Hancock is still firmly in the national spotlight.

title.children: In 1976, Australia's richest family looked to be a happy unit. It's a different story 40 years later

image.altText: Men walking through farm in dry mountain country in Afghanistan

items.synopsis: With the Taliban banning poppy production, this agriculture consultant from Darwin helps farmers in Afghanistan find viable and legal alternative crops.

title.children: Meet an Australian helping Afghan farmers find an alternative to opium poppies
